Office and the Nam Theun Watershed Management and Protection Authority,  
(ii)  leaders and citizens in twenty-five impacted villages, and  
(iii)  officials of six Nakai district offices.   
 
The findings also took into account the Report on Gender in Nam Thuen 2, conducted by 
IRAM in June 2004.

II.  Definition of Gender Planning 
A.  Elements for Gender Compliance   
 
Compared  to  men,  women  throughout  the  world  have  less  decision-making  power,  less 
education, less access and control over family resources, and therefore less ability to take risks 
and to cope with misfortune.  As such, gender is often labeled as a “women’s issue.”  However, 
gender in its broadest scope concerns the rights and opportunities for both women and men.  
Albeit less than women, men in all societies can experience gender inequities due to social and 
cultural traditions, expectations and stereotypes. 
 
For overall compliance, the GAPS has integrated into the SDP and SEMFOP two types of 
planning actions: 
 
(i)  Mainstream gender actions which are imbedded into primary activities, and 
(ii)  Women-specific  actions,  which  are  stand-alone  activities  to  promote  the 
capability, leadership and opportunity. 
 
The following is a summary of Gender Actions related to Project Impacted Areas, to Support 
Institutions, and Workers and Camp Followers.  
1.  Gender Actions within Project Impacted Areas  
 
Each Project Impacted Area (PIA) will witness varying degrees of positive and negative gender 
impacts. Key concerns focus largely on gender division of family and household labour and 
responsibility for food and livelihood security (farming, fishing, animal raising, foraging and 
hunting), and health and social security. In the Nakai Plateau, the enhancement of community 
structures within the resettlement process creates added institutional impacts related to gender.  
Women’s  political,  social  and  economic  empowerment  could  either  become  enhanced  or 
negated, depending on the level of gender sensitivity within project actions.   
 
The IRAM gender study found that women and girls, particularly those from certain marginalized 
ethnic groups and those living within disadvantaged households on the Nakai Plateau, are 
decidedly the most vulnerable and over-burdened social group.  In the past, the majority of 
these women and girls have had limited access to education, off-farm employment, production 
markets,  cash  assets,  and  socio-political  empowerment.  Even  slight  socio-economic 
disturbances could easily overwhelm their household coping mechanisms, deepen their already 
heavy family burdens, and over-stress their psychological welfare.  The gender risk is severe, 
requiring continual and intense gender technical support throughout the SDP.  
 
Therefore, the following gender impacts and gender-sensitive actions have been incorporated 
directly into the SDP and SEMFOP text as mainstreamed gender actions: 
 
(i)  Collection and analysis of disaggregated community data by gender, ethnicity 
and poverty levels: 
 
(ii)  Precise recording of original ownership (husband, wife, or both) of each family’s 
assets;   
(iii)  Use of the term “heads of household” and “heads of family” to recognize the 
hidden presence of female authority;

3.  Gender Actions Regarding NTPC Workers and Camp Followers 
 
Approximately 4000 workers (about ½ Lao citizens) and up to 16,000 camp followers (families 
of  workers  and  service  providers)  will  impact  heavily  on  the  social,  health  and  economic 
dynamics of all PIAs, especially in Nakai, Gnommalat and Lak Sao.  The population influx could 
prove explosive.  Strong social regulations and serious enforcement procedures are essential to 
avoid putting the security and health of the local population at risk.  
 
The combination of the dramatic population influx, the sudden increase in eating and drinking 
establishments and the availability of employment cash could certainly produced extremely high 
risks and negative impacts. Worldwide, gender concerns relate closely to five socio-economic 
issues, which often emerge significantly during large infrastructure construction projects:  
 
(i)  The increase in sexually transmitted infections (STI), most importantly HIV/AIDS; 
(ii)  The introduction of illegal trafficking problems, especially those involving women 
and young adolescents;

III.  Definition of Gender Mainstreaming 
 
A.  Description of Certain Gender Sensitive Actions  
 
This section highlights key gender-sensitive components of the GAPS.  Staff, advisory support 
and monitoring bodies of the SDP and SEMFOP will ensure implementation and monitoring of 
the recommended activities.    
1.  Identification of Vulnerable Families    
 
Within  all  communities,  certain  families  exhibit  more  vulnerabilities  than  others.  For  both 
resettlement and development efforts it is best to set a baseline ranking of each community’s 
families:  most  vulnerable,  average,  and  better-off.    This  participatory  process,  called 
Identification of Vulnerable Families (IVF):  
 
(i)  ensures inclusion of the most vulnerable families into training and development 
opportunities; 
(ii)  assesses stressful family circumstances, which impact heavily on women’s time, 
labor and well being; 
(iii)  includes  a  Wealth  Ranking  of  family  assets,  circumstances  and  social 
advantages; 
(iv)  provides a critical indicator for monitoring how well the most vulnerable families 
are coping with change; and  
(v)  signals where further safeguarding actions are needed.  
 
Therefore, performing IVF in all villages prior to resettlements in Nakai Plateau and prior to 
community planning in the Protected Watershed would be wise.  In the Gnommalat Channel 
and  the  Sebangfai  Downstream  areas,  IVF  will  be  used  selectively  in  the  most  severely 
impacted communities.     
 
Ideally,  each  community  during  a  participatory  identification  exercise  sets  its  criteria  for 
determining what factors constitute different levels of Vulnerable Families.  Using the Lao 
context, indicative factors for Identifying Vulnerable Households could include: 
 
(i)  Families with a single adult laborer (a woman or a man)supporting dependents; 
(ii)  Families with more than 5 children under the age of 10 years; 
(iii)  Families of elders only without nearby family support; 
(iv)  Families supporting dependent elderly or handicapped persons;  
(v)  Families in ethnically mixed communities that are in the ethnic minority;   
(vi)  Families with the least food security; 
(vii)  Families with the least wealth assets (animals, tools, mechanical equipment, 
bicycles, motorbikes, household items.)     
 
Communities can add or delete these factors, according to their circumstances. 
 
After a community has identified the factors for vulnerable families (high, medium, and low, or 
most disadvantaged, average or better-off), each household is assigned a symbol to note its 
vulnerability level. In this way, technical and community development staff will be able to ensure 
that highly Vulnerable Families are incorporated into training, decision-making session, and 
income-generating activities. Community Development experts will need to train staff on this 
process and the Monitoring and Evaluation team will need to monitor this process closely.

the Channel and Downstream zones, IVF may also need to be performed.

2.  Disaggregated Data Collection  
 
For the most part, the SDP’s process for collecting disaggregated baseline data by gender and 
by ethnic group is beginning to occur. (SEMFOP has not begun its field process yet.)  However, 
within villages and among villages further distinctions will need to be made.  As 3.1 suggests, 
judging  vulnerability  requires  the  disaggregation  of  a  combination  of  gender,  ethnicity  and 
poverty factors.  For example, the livelihood change-risks soar to the extreme for an illiterate 
ethnic minority family with only one woman adult labourer whose food security relies on upland 
rice growing, foraging and fishing.  On the other hand, a female-headed household with a male 
youth and access to paddy rice is much better off.  Therefore, particularly for the 17 resettling 
villages, a scaling system using the disaggregated data would be instrumental for pinpointing 
and  tracking  vulnerable  families  and  individuals.  Likewise,  a  scaling  system  on  village 
vulnerability within an area could be constructed to intensify support to high-risk communities. 
 
Concerning  disaggregated  data  on  families  and  households,  four  concerns  need  further 
attention and clarification.    
 
First, when recording family land and household assets, gender ownership should be carefully 
recorded. Often household and farming land and assets belong equally to male and female 
heads of household. However, in some cases only one spouse owns through inheritance the 
land or the assets. Depending on the ethnic group, a man or a woman in the Lao PDR can 
inherit land and valuable goods.  To assume both spouses own the land or assets together 
could create tensions and legal problems. Therefore, recorders will need first to ask both the 
husband and the wife who is the original owner of the land or asset.  If ownership is with one 
  7

Supplementary Appendix C 
person, he / she has the option to share or not to share the land and assets with a spouse.1  In 
this way, a gender-sensitive approach for both men and women is achieved.    
 
Second,  a  clear  distinction  needs  to  be  made  between  “household”  and  “family.”    Many 
households are multi-family in the Lao PDR.  Within a household designated as well-off, there 
could exist a hidden high risk family (adult and children).  This is especially important within 
ethnic groups with multiple wives.        
 
Third, when listing household decision-makers, it is preferable to use the gender-sensitive 
terminology of “heads of household” and “heads of family.”  In this way, the two lead persons, 
usually  the  husband  and  the  wife,  are  both  recognized  equally  for  land  registration, 
compensation, training and decision-making.  Traditionally, within most ethnic groups in the Lao 
PDR, women usually hold authority over socio-economic decisions and men over political ones.  
Thus, especially when encouraging socio-economic development (agriculture, small livestock 
raising, marketing, informal and formal trading,) women’s roles can be significant, though less 
obvious to outsiders.  
 
Fourth, labour division by gender and age can vary significantly among the ethnic groups and 
within an ethnic group depending on its isolation.  There are differences, for example, on labour 
division patterns between the Brou living on the Nakai Plateau and those in the Protected 
Watershed.    Certain  household  and  field  tasks  vary  depending  on  their  remoteness  and 
exposure to other cultural ways.  For example, men often cook more than women in Brou 
households in the distance Watershed villages. Also, men help with childcare in the evenings 
when women are in the fields, fetching water and pounding rice pounding. Consequently, both 
men and women would benefit from training on food preparation and preservation, and on 
childcare.  Therefore, it is essential to collect and analyze gender-disaggregated data on labour 
division in each village, and set detailed planning implementation accordingly. 
 
Recommended Actions For Insertion into RAP and SEMFOP: 
 
(i)  Train and monitor all staff and technical experts on the reasons for collecting and 
analyzing  gender  disaggregated  data  and  the  use  of  gender-sensitive 
terminology. 
(ii)  Ensure  that  land  and  assets  surveys  and  registration,  particularly  the 
compensation cases in the Gnommalat Reservoir and Channel Area, recognize 
the rights of original single owners, regardless of sex.  
(iii)  Collect and analyze data on each village’s pattern for labour division by gender 
and age. 
(iv)  Ensure detailed action plans and implementation correspond correctly to gender 
labour  divisions,  especially  in  the  agriculture,  livestock-raising  and  forestry 
sectors.

4.  Code for Staff Regulations and Enforcement Process 
 
Trust in and respect for outside professionals are key ingredients for successful change in any 
development  or  resettlement  situation.    Villagers  quickly  judge  the  integrity  of  community 
developers and technicians by every day work and living habits.  In addition, the power of

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Given the relatively small size of Lao PDR’s economy and population, the Nam Theun 2 
Hydroelectric Project (the Project) has the potential to have quite significant macroeconomic 
impacts.  In  this  report,  we  assess  the  impact  that  the  project  is  likely  to  have  on  the 
macroeconomy, as well as how this may then translate into poverty outcomes in the country. 
2.  In addressing the poverty implications of the Project, it is important to distinguish the 
direct macroeconomic impact from the impact possible from alternative uses of the income 
stream accruing to the Government as a result of the project. It is important to emphasize at the 
outset  that  this  report  focuses  on  the  poverty  implications  deriving  from  the  direct 
macroeconomic impacts alone. In other words, we focus on the construction phase rather than 
the operational phase. 
3.  The large capital investment (approximately $1.2 billion) will generate a very sizable 
income stream for the next three decades and beyond. Through taxes, royalties and dividends, 
the people of Lao PDR stand to be major beneficiaries. The boost in revenues will strengthen 
the Government’s capacity to provide the public goods and services essential for sustainable 
growth and poverty reduction.  Although this revenue stream could have a significant influence 
on economic and social conditions, they are noted but not analyzed here because they do not 
form part of the direct macroeconomic impacts of the project. 
4.  The report is organized as follows. After a brief overview of the Lao economy, the likely 
macroeconomic impacts are examined. This is followed by an analysis of the likely poverty 
impacts  resulting  from  the  direct  macroeconomic  changes  induced  by  the  Project.  A  final 
section summarizes the main points. 
II.  ECONOMIC OVERVIEW 
5.  Lao PDR is classified as a less developed country (LDC), with GDP per capita of about 
$330.  Annual  GDP  growth  has  averaged  about  6.5%  over  the  past  decade,  and  most 
projections point to a continuing of this trend for the next few years at the very least. Years of 
continuous strong growth has lead to an appreciable decline in poverty incidence (see Section 
IV). The agricultural sector contributes more than 50% of GDP and employs about 80% of the 
workforce. In this regard, Lao PDR’s economic prospects continue to hinge crucially on the 
performance of this sector.  
 
6.  With the introduction of its "New Economic Mechanism" in 1986, Lao PDR has been 
gradually  transforming  its  economy,  shifting  from  a  centrally  planned  to  a  market-oriented 
system. Reforms have been pursued in several areas, including trade policy, public expenditure 
management, natural resources management, state-owned enterprises, and the banking sector.  
Although much has been achieved in these areas over the years, many challenges remain. 
 
7.  One of the most significant challenges facing the government relates to improving the 
collection  and  management  of  public  revenues  and  increasing  transparency  and 
accountability in the use of public funds. The share of government revenue in GDP continues to 
hover around the 10–12% mark and, with limited room to maneuver on the expenditure front, 
this often leads to budget deficits that put upward pressure on inflation. Lao PDR has been 
susceptible to episodes of hyperinflation in the recent past, and inflation continues to linger in 
the low double-digits.

2   
 
8.  Lao  PDR’s  major  exports  include  electricity,  minerals,  garments  and  coffee,  whilst 
almost all of its demands for manufactured (consumer and capital) goods are imported. Most of 
its trade is conducted within the region, with Thailand as its main trading partner, and largest 
investor. The external debt stock is estimated at about $2 billion in 2004. However, given the 
concessional nature of the majority of this debt, the debt service ratio remains at a manageable 
level of less than 10%. 
 
III.  MACROECONOMIC IMPACTS 
9.  The main impacts of the Project on the macroeconomy are likely to operate through 
changes in economic growth and the real exchange rate. 
A.  Impact on Economic Growth  
10.  Since Lao PDR’s economy is not fully employed, this large construction project will have 
a significant impact on output and employment. It is estimated that the Nam Theun 2 project 
could lead to an almost doubling in private investment during the construction phase (IMF, 
2003). Approximately $350 million will be spent in Lao PDR during the 4.5 year construction 
period for civil works. The construction phase (approximately 54 months) will employ up to 
4,000 workers, and an estimated 16,000 dependents and job seekers (for various support 
services) will concentrate in the site area. There will also be multiplier effects, as the first round 
of income leads to expenditure and income for others, who in turn spend. 
11.  The net effect of these factors could be a boost in economic growth over the base case 
by perhaps as much as a full percentage point during the construction phase. Currently, the 
growth rate is about 6.5%, and so a rate of 7-7.5% is possible during the 2006 to 2011 period, 
ceteris paribus.1 
B.  Growth in Income and Per Capita Consumption  
12.  The  higher  GDP  growth  rate  will  lead  to  higher  personal  income  and  per  capita 
consumption. But this effect is likely to be small relative to other sources of GDP growth. As 
noted above, most of the investment demand will take the form of imported capital equipment. 
Furthermore, most of the income stream in the first ten years of operation will accrue to debt 
holders and foreign shareholders. Drawing on the relationship between GDP growth and growth 
in per capita consumption evidenced between 1992/93 and 1997/98, and discounting by 50% to 
reflect the high degree of imported inputs associated with the Project, growth in per capita 
consumption could increase by half a percentage point, from 3.5 to about 4% per annum as a 
result of the Project. 
C.  Exchange Rate Effects  
13.  An increase in capital inflows (during the construction phase) and a sharp increase in 
export earnings (from the sale of power to Thailand) could be expected to result in appreciation 
of the domestic currency. At face value, the Project has all the ingredients necessary to produce 
a typical “Dutch Disease” type outcome. Normally, we would expect Dutch Disease type effects

to  operate  by  adversely  affecting  the  competitiveness  of  other  export  sectors  through 
appreciation of the real exchange rate, resulting in a widening trade deficit.   
14.  But the economy of Lao PDR is not altogether typical. There are not too many other 
export sectors to be adversely affected, and some may be insulated to some extent by either 
special arrangements (preferential access to its main markets in the case of clothing) or the 
presence of non-market conditions (informal cross border trade in the case of timber).  Even if 
Dutch Disease type effects do not have a significant adverse effect on other export sectors, they 
would serve to delay, or compromise, the process of diversification of the export base itself. In 
other  words,  not  only  would  Nam  Theun  2  directly  contribute  to  export  concentration  by 
increasing the share of electricity exports in total exports, the Dutch Disease type effects that it 
would  induce  through  the  real  exchange  rate  may  create  a  further  impediment  to  the 
development of new export industries. This could contribute to increased risk of export instability 
in the future.  
15.  In large measure, the likelihood of Dutch Disease type effects depends on the extent of 
the real exchange rate appreciation. The extent of the appreciation, in real terms, is difficult to 
estimate however.2  
16.  In order to gain some insight on the issue, we look at movements in the real exchange 
rate during the 1990s and the beginning of this decade, but excluding the turbulent post-Asian 
financial crisis period. Capital inflows increased during the early 1990s and then more recently, 
resulting  in  both  cases  in  some  appreciation  in  the  real  exchange  rate.  Based  on  this 
experience, and after adjusting for the high import content of the Nam Theun 2 project, the real 
appreciation in the exchange rate as a result of the project could be in the order of 1.7% during 
the construction phase. During the operational phase, real appreciation of the exchange rate as 
a result of the project would be an estimated 0.75%. These rates of appreciation are considered 
“moderate and manageable but not zero” (Warr, 2004).3  
17.  Despite being small in magnitude, the appreciation of the real exchange rate would 
nevertheless  put  traded  goods  at  a  disadvantage.  Exchange  rate  appreciation  from  large 
investments  in  capital-intensive  industries  can  pose  a  threat  to  Lao  PDR’s  comparative 
advantage in agriculture, forestry and low wage light manufacturing and service industries. Lao 
PDR’s exports would become more costly to foreign buyers, while imports for Lao consumers 
would become less expensive. It could also adversely affect tourism. In short, the competitive 
position of Lao products and services would be weakened. The issue of competitiveness is of 
growing importance, as Lao PDR becomes increasingly open and subject to regional and global 
trade liberalization pressures, such as under the ASEAN Free Trade Agreement (AFTA) and 
through their pursuit of membership of the WTO. 
18.  While the Project is not perceived to pose a serious problem in terms of Dutch Disease 
type  effects,  concentration  in  capital  intensive  industries  in  the  future  could  undermine 
prospects for the rapidly growing labour force, as well as increase vulnerability to terms of trade 
shocks.

IV.  POVERTY IMPACTS 
A.  Introduction 
19.  Lao PDR is the least developed of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries and 
one of the poorest countries in Asia, both in terms of per capita income and in terms of various 
social indicators. Preliminary estimates from the Lao Expenditure and Consumptions Survey III 
(LECS III) indicate a decrease in the incidence of poverty from 39% in 1997/98 to 32% in 
2003/03.4 The LECS III data also indicate a more equitable growth pattern between 1997/98 
and 2002/03, largely as a result of strong growth in the agricultural sector. Despite this sharp 
reduction over a five-year period, poverty incidence remains unacceptably high in Lao PDR. 
B.  Poverty Implications of the Macroeconomic Impacts 
20.  The main impact on poverty incidence is likely to come from the boost to economic 
growth. If the Project results in a one-percentage point increase in the GDP growth rate during 
the construction phase (between 2006–2011), then there is likely to be a discernable reduction 
in poverty incidence. 
21.  As illustrated by the experience of neighboring countries such as Thailand, Viet Nam, 
PRC  etc.,  rapid  economic  growth  can  be  the  single most important contributor to poverty 
reduction (ADB, 2004a). In Lao PDR, the 6.3% average growth rate in GDP during the 1992/93 
to 1997/98 period contributed to the reduction in the incidence of poverty from 46% to 39%. 
Preliminary data from the LECS III indicates that the continued growth rate of about 6% has 
resulted in a further reduction in the incidence (headcount) of poverty to about 32%.  
22.  As an approximation based on a simple average, a sustained 6% growth rate over a 
five-year period appears to reduce the incidence of poverty by about 7 percentage points. 
Based on recent historical experience, then each percentage point of growth sustained over a 
five-year period appears to reduce the incidence of poverty by 1.2 percentage points. This is not 
to ignore the factors other than economic growth that would have contributed to this reduction in 
poverty. But if we assume that these other factors continue to play an unchanged role into the 
future, then one could deduce that the Nam Theun 2 project, with its expected one percentage 
point boost to GDP growth during 2006–2011, would contribute to lowering the incidence of 
poverty by up to 1.2 percentage points annually 5 If this is the case, the combined GDP effect of 
the Nam Theun 2 project during the construction phase could help lift approximately 60,000 
people above the poverty line annually. 
23.  It could be expected that project site areas such as Khammouane Province would be the 
main beneficiary, provided all the environmental and social mitigation measures are fully and 
successfully  implemented  (ADB,  2004b).  Neighboring  provinces  (Borikhamxay  and

V.  CONCLUSIONS 
24.  The macroeconomic impact of the Nam Theun 2 project is expected to be positive as a 
result of the boost to GDP growth driven mainly by a sharp increase in private sector investment 
during the construction phase. While most of the investment will be incurred for imported 
equipment, civil works will directly employ some 4,000 workers. Together with multiplier effects, 
GDP growth could be spurred by up to a full percentage point in each year of the construction 
phase. It is unlikely that there will be significant Dutch Disease type effects since the expected 
appreciation of the real exchange rate is likely to be small. Nevertheless, competitiveness of the 
traded  goods  sector  will  be  adversely  affected,  but  this  effect  could  be  mitigated  through 
reforms that increase productivity.  
25.  Given that economic growth is the main determinant of poverty reduction, the positive 
growth effects of the Nam Theun 2 project could contribute significantly to poverty reduction. 
Based on recent historical experience, it is estimated that the combined GDP effect of the Nam 
Theun 2 project during the construction phase could help lift approximately 60,000 people up 
above the poverty line annually. 
26.  Having said that however, it should be noted that the poverty situation in Lao PDR is 
complex, interwoven with the ethnic fabric that so characterizes the country. In this report, we 
have focused only on the direct macroeconomic impacts of the project. If the revenues accruing 
to the government are well managed and efficiently employed to address poverty and social 
conditions, then the benefits to the Lao people could be substantially greater than the positive 
macroeconomic impacts described here. The provision of additional electricity to the areas 
within and adjacent to the project site would also contribute to improved living conditions.

DETAILED ECONOMIC ANALYSIS - THE NAM THEUN 2 HYDROELCTRIC PROJECT 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Nam Theun 2 (NT2) Project is a hydroelectric project of about 1,000 megawatts (MW)1 in 
the Lao People's Democratic Republic (PDR) to be developed by a private company, Nam 
Theun 2 Power Company (NTPC). The Government of Lao (GOL) is a 25% shareholder in 
NTPC, sharing ownership with a consortium of foreign sponsors including Electricité de France 
International  (EDF,  35%)  and  two  Thai  companies,  Electricity  Generating  Public  Company 
(EGCO, 25%) and Italian-Thai Development Public Company Ltd (ITD, 15%). Upon anticipated 
commencement of commercial operation in November 2009, NTPC will sell power at pre-
negotiated prices to the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT) and to Electricité du 
Laos (EdL). While the NT2 Project will be operated and maintained by NTPC, the generation 
serving Thailand will be under the full dispatch control of EGAT. 
2.  In the following paragraphs, the economic impact of the proposed project is evaluated 
from the regional perspective, including both Thailand and Lao PDR, and from the Lao PDR 
country perspective.  The analysis begins with a summary of electricity demand and expansion 
planning in each country.  It then proceeds to a valuation of project costs and benefits, followed 
by an assessment of the project economic rate of return (EIRR) for both the region and for Lao 
PDR.  Sensitivity and risk analysis was conducted for each perspective.  Finally, the report 
considers the distribution of economic benefits among stakeholders across the region.   
B.  Thailand 
1.  Demand Forecast 
3.  Load forecasting in Thailand is a collaborative effort of the major stakeholders. The 
Thailand Load Forecast Sub-committee (TLFS)2 considers a number of methodologies, and 
reviews  the  work  of  participating  agencies  before  integrating  results  into  a  national  load 
forecast.  Forecasting techniques vary by:  
(i)  distribution  company  (Metropolitan  Electricity  Authority  [MEA]  in  greater 
Bangkok, and Provincial Electricity Authority [PEA] in the rest of the country); 
(ii)  customer class (i.e., residential, small and large business, industrial, etc.); and 
(iii)  forecast horizon (i.e., short-term or long-term).  
4.  Four  methods  are  used  for  energy  forecasting.  Two  of  these  methods  might  be 
described as “bottom up” in that they depend on detailed knowledge of end-users, while two 
others might be characterized as “top down”, since they depend on macroeconomic trends.

however, designates the plant as 920 MW, the estimated minimum monthly delivery. The difference between the 
two numbers is (i) transmission losses to the purchase-point at the Thai border, and (ii) what one EGAT official 
calls a “margin of security” for the sake of system reliability. The power purchase agreement (PPA) is priced in 
terms of GWh and hence the MW definition is not important for purposes of this analysis.

the Thailand Development and Research Institute (TDRI).

(i)  End-Use Model: Consumption for residential customers throughout Thailand is

appliance  saturation,  and  expected  appliance  efficiency  improvement.  In 
addition, EGAT’s large direct-service customers are forecast by individual firm

region  and  by  business  sector  so  that  energy  consumption  relationships  by 
sector  can  be  evaluated.  Total  consumption  is  derived  based  on  historical 
consumption per unit of gross regional product (GRP), and the forecast growth in 
GRP by sector. The energy intensity model is used where “first hand” sources 
(e.g.,  Board  of  Expansion  data,  and  surveys  of  available  floor  space)  are 
unavailable, especially for longer-term forecasting; 
(iv)  Econometric Regression: When class consumption patterns are not attributed to 
clearly  identifiable  relationships  (e.g.,  appliance  usage,  floor  space,  sector 
energy intensity), econometric regression is used to define the relationship. The 
method is particularly applied to small business, and to other classes in which 
users have widely diverse consumption characteristics; and 
(v)  Peak Demand Model: The TLFS has developed substantial load research data 
by customer group over recent years through extensive surveys, and applies this 
information  to  project  demand  from  energy  forecasts  developed  using  the 
foregoing methods. The number of customers within each class is forecast based 
on regression analysis, and daily load curves derived from the load research data 
are  used  to  forecast  coincident  and  non-coincident  peak  for  each  customer 
group. Peak losses are also forecast via regression equations for each customer 
class.  
 
5.  Growth in electricity demand is highly correlated to medium and long-term economic 
growth prospects. The TLFS relies on the economic forecasts of the Government of Thailand 
(GOT)  as  prepared  by  the  National  Economic  and  Social  Development  Board  (NESDB).  
NESDB typically forecasts national GDP only for five years, so TLFS has employed TDRI to 
project longer-term economic growth and to disaggregate the national GDP forecast by region 
and by business sector.

2.  Least Cost Expansion 
8.  Thailand’s domestic natural resources for power generation include natural gas, lignite 
and hydropower. The current electricity capacity consists of combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) 
(71%), thermal (lignite and oil, 19%), hydropower (9%) and other smaller sources (1%). EGAT 
has historically supplemented these resources with imported oil. It is likely that Thailand will 
continue to rely on natural gas as a major fuel source as it is environmentally friendly and 
provides an efficient source of power generation. However, continued reliance on natural gas 
will require further investment in the gas pipeline network and imports from its neighbors. Heavy 
reliance on one fuel source may also cause undesirable price fluctuations. Thailand is therefore 
keen to diversify its fuel sources, including domestic coal-fired coal plants and hydropower 
imports from Lao PDR and Myanmar.

C.  Lao PDR 
1.  Demand and Supply 
13.  The Lao PDR electricity supply system is small in comparison with the Thai system. It 
consists of four grids, none of which are interconnected. Demand is characterized by relatively 
low per capita consumption and a low electrification rate compared to other countries in the 
region. The current electricity consumption is estimated at 211 kWh/capita per year and the 
household electrification rate is about 40%. Historically, domestic consumption has been small 
in relation to total production and exports. However, this situation has changed over the past 
decade (Table SAF. 3). Imports have increased as a share of total domestic production, and the 
share of exports has declined. Domestic consumption account for more than two-thirds of total 
domestic production. In 2003, electricity exports (in GWh) were less than half the level of 
domestic consumption. The NT2 Project would increase Lao exports by at least 5,354 GWh 
annually, and generate an additional 200-300 GWh for domestic use.

21.  The PSDP analyzed 33 separate hydro projects and two thermal projects within Lao 
PDR that had been identified in previous studies. These candidates included projects with 
potential for (i) providing export earnings and/or (ii) meeting domestic power needs. Each 
project was evaluated on a standalone basis, and (when appropriate) in conjunctive operation 
with other projects in the following process: 
(i)  Projects were initially evaluated solely on a technical basis, and compared on the 
basis of specific generation cost.  For hydro projects, weighted average cost of 
generation was calculated assuming a value of secondary energy at half the rate for 
primary  energy.      Optimal  hydro  project  configurations were  developed  using  a 
proprietary  project  dimensioning  and  evaluation  program  (“EVALS”),15  which 
evaluated alternative dam heights and installed capacity factors (ICF)16 according to 
assumptions about the project and its circumstances. The program dimensioned 
project elements, simulated and optimized reservoir operation, estimated costs of 
construction and operation, and calculated key outputs including capital cost, firm 
and non-firm energy, and the cost of energy production.  Costs for the NT2 Project 
were developed by EVALS (i.e., rather than being based the PPA tariff); however 
project configuration was based on the design as contractually committed.    
(ii)  Shortlisted  projects  were  evaluated  in  more  detail.17    Project  cash  flows  were 
adjusted to incorporate the monetary value of social and environmental impacts as 
measured via a proprietary spreadsheet model (“SESAMEE”).18 The model ultimately 
reduces  project  impacts  –  resulting  from  construction  sites,  transmission  lines, 
access roads, reservoir and catchment areas, and downstream rivers, etc. – to cash 
flows,  providing  estimates  of  dollar  costs  and  benefits  for  each  year  of  project 
construction and operation. SESAMEE produced both a global project ranking based 
on global standards and market values, and a local project ranking based on local 
standards and market values.19

b.  Project Benefits 
30.  Benefits were derived on the basis of defining electricity consumption from NT2 as non-
incremental that replaces existing supply of energy, and incremental if it meets additional or 
induced  demand.  Benefits  were  classified  as  incremental  and  non-incremental  taking  into 
account the following considerations: 
(i)  Project sales to Thailand will go to the national grid. The grid serves the entire 
country,  and  Thailand  is  nearly  100%  electrified.  Load  growth  for  all  customer 
segments  is  characterized  by  incremental  growth  in  consumption  of  existing 
customers, new household formation and non-household economic expansion. Thus, 
NT2 sales to Thailand are assumed to be incremental. This represents 97% of the 
sales. 
(ii)  The electricity system in Lao PDR is comprised of four major grids, none of which 
are currently interconnected. The Central-2 grid serves the region in which the NT2 
project  is  located  (Khammouane  and  Savannakhet  Provinces).  The  primary 
generation source for the area is imports from Thailand, both directly to some larger 
customers,  and  indirectly  through  sales  to  local  area  grids.  Substitution  (import

Supplementary Appendix F   15
substitution) in Lao PDR will replace imports coming from two different sources:  (a) 
direct cross-border sales to EdL for larger grid offtakes (at $0.065/kWh), and (b) 
sales  by  Thailand’s  Provincial  Electricity  Authority  (PEA)  to  larger  industrial 
customers and town grids at both medium and low voltage levels (at $0.073/kWh). 
Therefore, all Lao purchases from the NT2 Project is defined as non-incremental. 
This represents the remaining 3% of the sales from the NT2 Project. 
31.  Non-incremental benefits of electricity are valued based on the financial cost of supply 
without the project (appropriately converted to economic costs with shadow conversion factors), 
whereas incremental benefits are valued at an average of the cost of electricity without and with 
the  project.  The  benefit  for  non-incremental  electricity  is  based  on  the  economic  cost  of 
substitutes, in this case imported electricity. Incremental benefits are valued at the average 
willingness to pay for electricity estimated as the weighted average of the cost of the alternative 
energy source and the anticipated electricity tariff.

E.  Project Economic Internal Rate of Return 
35.  The basis for the project evaluation is a comparison of discounted benefits and costs 
between the with-project and the without project cases. The discount factor of 12% represents 
the opportunity cost of capital. The project period of analysis is 30 years, with commissioning in 
2010.  The  project  construction  period  is  4.5  years,  commencing  in  2005.  However,  pre-
development costs start in 2004. 
36.  Although the NT2 Project is a regional project, its economic impact on the region is not 
identical to its impact on the sponsoring country.  Hence, the project has been evaluated from 
the distinct perspectives of the region and of Lao PDR. 
a.  Regional Perspective  
37.  From the regional perspective, the NT2 Project costs and benefits follow the description 
set forth in the foregoing section.  The project economic cost includes the pre-development and 
construction costs for the NT2 Project, plus the cost of the associated transmission line being 
funded separately.  Benefits include sales of energy to Thailand (incremental sales) and Lao 
PDR (non-incremental sales).  
38.  The NT2 Project will result in an annual reduction of 275 GWh for the existing Theun 
Hinboun IPP hydro project (THH), which shares the catchment area with the NT2 Project.  
Although this cost was known and included in the original planning for THH, it is a real resource 
cost and therefore included as a negative benefit in the project resource statement.    
39.  The NT2 Project will reduce Thai exports to Lao by approximately 200-300 GWh per 
year, and this might be considered a project benefit, since these resources will be available for 
use in Thailand.  However, Thailand will also lose an equivalent value in export revenues, 
meaning that Thailand will gain no economic advantage.30  This benefit has not been included in 
the resource statement. 
40.  The resource statement does not include any disbenefits resulting from environmental or 
social costs; currently available information suggests that these costs are incorporated to a 
large extent into project direct capital and operating costs.  Specifically, a total of $130 million 
(at current market prices) has been allocated to environmental and social programs (including 
$49 million for pre-operations programs, $22 million for loss of future eco-tourism potential, and 
$59 milion for annual operating costs related to environmental and social programs). Only a 
small area (ca 250 hectares) of actively cultivated land is being removed from agricultural 
production, and relocated households are being given replacement land with greater agricultural 
potential.  Evidence to date suggests that the local population may gain from the implementation 
of  the  Project.    Considerable  effort  by  Lao  PDR,  developers,  and  international  funding 
institutions has been devoted to identifying and monetizing environmental and social costs as 
part of the project.  All of these costs are included in the project economic resource statement.   
41.  The average incremental economic cost is estimated at $0.036/kWh. The economic net 
present value (NPV) is estimated $269 million or $0.013/kWh. The economic internal rate of 
return (EIRR) is 15.9%. The summary of economic analysis is presented in Table SAF.12.

F.  Sensitivity Analysis 
46.  Sensitivity analysis of the regional EIRR results was undertaken with respect to key risk 
factors and assumptions expected to influence the viability of the NT2 Project (Table SAF.14). 
The sensitivity analysis shows that the NPV would decrease by 51% to $133 million and EIRR 
to 13.7% if investment cost would increase by 20%. A five-year reduction in the operating life of 
the project would reduce the EIRR marginally to 15.6%. Conservative benefits assumptions 
representing 20% reduction in benefits and a 1-year delay of benefits would reduce the EIRR to 
13.0% and 14.2%, respectively. Adjustments in the assumptions of conversion factors and 
discount rates have only a minor impact on EIRR. None of the risk factors would independently 
undermine  the  conclusion  of  the  economic  viability  of  the  NT2  Project.  However,  if  cost 
increases if 20% are combined with a 20% reduction in benefits, the EIRR would fall just below 
the opportunity cost of capital. Furthermore, if this scenario is combined with a 1-year delay of 
benefits and a 5-year reduction in operating life, the EIRR would fall to 9.1%.  
47.  A parallel sensitivity analysis of the Lao EIRR was also prepared, as reported in Table 
SAF.15.  The analysis showed results very similar to the regional sensitivity tests.  Estimated 
EIRR’s reported for each Lao PDR test were from 0.2 to 0.4% lower than the regional results, 
reflecting the lower base case Lao-specific EIRR.  As with the regional investigation, only tests 
considering pessimistic outcomes for combinations of variables produced an overall rate of 
return below the opportunity cost of capital.

G.  Risk Analysis 
48.  A risk analysis was carried out using XLSim.32 to analyze the range of project outcomes 
by allowing multiple risk factors to vary randomly (within a defined range). Four key risk factors 
were identified, including; (i) capital cost; (ii) annual operating cost; (iii) sales to EGAT during 
peak hours (“PE” sales); and (iv) incremental benefits (which are directly related to the avoided 
cost of power in Thailand. Probability distributions were assigned to each variable as follows: 
(i)  Capital during the construction period, and operating costs over the project life 
were allowed to vary randomly from 95% (low) to 110% (high), with an average 
of 100% (i.e., their point-value in the model. This choice can be rationalized on 
the grounds that fixed price contracts are in place, so that substantial savings are 
not expected, and contractors are required to share cost overruns. 
 
(ii)  PE Sales to EGAT were allowed to vary based on a triangular distribution of 
values, based on the range of GWh generation estimated from hydrologic data 
from the project area (1953-1999). The assumed range is 3667 GWh (low), 4,406 
GWh (mean), and 4,528 GWh (high).  
 
(iii)  The value of incremental benefits were allowed to vary from 90 to 110% (around 
an average of 100%), reflecting the uncertainty surrounding the point-values

H.  Distribution of Project Benefits 
50.  The costs and benefits of the NT2 Project will be shared among different stakeholders 
and  countries.  A  project  may  be  economically  viable  without  necessarily  helping  intended 
recipients. The assessment of the distribution of project benefits helps to identify who gains and 
who loses from a project. Since the economic analysis was made from a regional perspective, 
including both Thailand and Lao PDR, intra-regional transfer payments such as the export 
revenue earnings, taxes and royalties for Lao PDR are not included in the economic analysis. 
However, these transfers become visible in the distribution analysis.    
51.  The costs and benefits of the project, both in financial and economic terms, have been 
discounted using  the  discount  rate  of  12%.  To  make  the  financial  and  economic  analysis 
comparable, it was necessary to account for the cost of Thailand transmission line in the 
financial analysis, since this cost is included in the economic analysis of the project.  
52.  The primary interest of the distribution analysis is to ensure that Lao PDR receives a fair 
share of the project benefits, especially considering that 95% of the NT2 Project sales accrue to 
Thailand.  Table  SAF.17  shows  the  distribution  analysis  with  Thailand  treated  as  one 
stakeholder  (but  includes  private  company  developers  and  consumers),  and  Lao  PDR 
separated into three stakeholders, including the GOL/Economy, labor and electricity consumers. 
In addition, the largest equity investor, EdF is also accounted for. Gains and losses (e.g. the 
differences  between  financial  and  economic  costs  and  benefits)  are  assigned  to  each 
stakeholder.  
53.  The consumer surplus, representing a gain to consumers due to the fact that project 
benefits exceed the tariff, is allocated to Lao and Thai consumers based on the sales shares to 
each  country.  The  economic  valuation  of  tradables  exceeds  its  financial  value  due  to  the 
application of the SERF. The cost of the overvaluation of the exchange rate is borne by the 
GOL, and represents a loss to the economy as a whole (and especially to importers). The 
financial cost of unskilled labor exceeds its opportunity cost, with the difference reflecting a net 
gain  to  unskilled  labor  participating  in  the  project.  Taxes  and  royalties  paid  to  Lao  PDR 
represent a gain for those public goals for which the GOL elects to commit its resources. GOL, 
as a 25% equity shareholder in the NT2 Project, also realizes a financial gain, reflected in the 
amount by which financial benefits exceed financial costs.  
 
54.  Overall, the economic NPV exceeds the financial NPV by $251 million. The greatest 
beneficiary is the Lao PDR economy with net benefits of about $171 million of which taxes and 
royalties to the Government account for 52%.  Project investors will receive about $18 million 
(including the GOL).  The total gains to Thailand amount to $74 million of which consumers in 
Thailand  receive  a  net  benefit  amounting  to  $67  million  (after  netting  out  the  cost  of  the 
transmission line and the loss of THH energy).  Lao consumers also benefit, albeit a smaller 
amount.  However, the conservative estimate of the annual off-take from NT2 to Lao consumers 
represents a substantial share, about 7%, of total national energy consumption in 2010. 
I.  Conclusion 
55.  Economic  evaluation  of  the  NT2  Project  indicates  that  the  planned  investment  is 
economically viable.  The estimated economic rate of return (EIRR) is 15.9% when analyzed 
from the regional perspective while it is 15.5% from the Lao perspective.  Moreover, the project 
remains viable from both points of view when subjected to pessimistic sensitivity tests.  Project 
returns fall below the opportunity cost of capital (12%) only when a combination of adverse cost

can be expected to achieve an economic rate of return above the opportunity cost of capital.

10.  As discussed above, NTPC’s equity and debt structure has been specifically designed 
to hedge the company’s exposure to changes in US dollar and THB exchange rates. Under its 
existing financing plan, the company would also hedge its interest rate exposure on US dollar 
debt by swapping its floating rate loans to a fixed rate. However, the plan presented in the 
base case financial model does not presently incorporate any interest rate hedging on THB 
debt. Therefore, under this plan, NTPC is fully exposed to fluctuations in interest rates on its 
entire THB debt. This debt could be converted to a fixed rate though an interest rate swap, 
similar to that planned for the US dollar floating rate debt.  However, the size and liquidity of 
the THB interest rate swap market is much more limited than that for US dollar swaps. This 
significantly limits the maturities available and means that costs are higher than that for US 
dollar interest rate swaps.

agreement, EdL/EGAT power purchase agreements, EGAT security documents, financing 
documents, head construction contract, preliminary construction works contracts, insurance 
policies,  operation  and  maintenance  agreements,  project  base  case,  project  coordination 
agreements);  (ii)  adequate  reserves  for  working  capital  or  other  purposes  as  deemed 
appropriate by shareholders; and (iii) the provisions of the financing documents. 
 
18.  Accounts Receivable & Payables. Accounts receivable consist entirely of the tariffs 
billed  to  EGAT  and  EdL  that  have  not  yet  been  paid  to  NTPC.  This  is  assumed  to  be 
equivalent to one month of projected billing in each year over the concession period. Accounts 
payable consist of that portion of operating and maintenance expenses incurred, but not yet 
paid by NTPC. This is also assumed to be equivalent to one month of such expenses.

Supplementary Appendix H   
DETAILED NAM THEUN 2 POWER COMPANY (NTPC) FINANCIAL PROJECTIONS 
 
1.  Objectives & Scope.  Financial projections have been prepared for the Nam Theun 2 
Power Company Limited (NTPC) in order to assess the financial viability and sustainability of 
the company over the operating period of the Concession Agreement (CA). Based on the 
current schedule, this would extend from November 2009 to November 2034. The projections 
consist  of  annual  financial  statements  (income  statement,  cash  flow  statement,  balance 
sheet),  key  performance  indicators,  and  supporting  operating  and  financial  data  for  the 
company.  The  methodology  and  scope  of  the  analysis  presented  in  this  supplementary 
appendix is consistent with that prescribed by ADB’s Guidelines for the Financial Governance 
and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian Development Bank (2002). 
 
2.  The financial projections are based on those generated by a financial model that was 
prepared for NTPC by its financial advisors. The model is intended to illustrate the financial 
performance of the company over the entire operating period of the concession under a base 
case scenario. This base case reflects what the project sponsors and its financial advisors 
deem to be a most likely set of outcomes regarding the financial position and performance of 
NTPC. A detailed review of the model indicated that the inputs and assumptions employed in 
preparing the base case projections for NTPC are generally reasonable. 
 
3.  The key assumptions employed in the preparation of the financial projections are set 
out in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
4.  Projected Financial Performance.  Under the base case, NTPC is projected to be 
profitable in each year over the operational period of the concession. Over the first five years 
of  operations  (2009–2014)  net  income  averages  about  $69  million  per  year  on  average 
operating revenue of $221 million. Over this period, annual growth in net income is high 
relative to the remainder of the concession, averaging almost 13% between 2011 and 2014.  
This relatively higher rate of growth occurs because interest expense declines significantly as 
the company repays its debt, while tax and royalty rates remain low. Beyond 2014, net income 
increases more gradually and is projected to peak at $141 million in 2024. With higher tax and 
royalty rates being implemented, net income follows a gradual downward trend over the 
remainder of the concession. 
 
5.  Consistent with relatively stable net income levels, the projected annual return on 
equity (ROE) is also relatively stable, particularly over the first 10 years of the concession.  
The average ROE over this period is projected to be 17.8% and just slightly lower, 16.4%, over 
the first five years of operations. While these levels appear to be commercially acceptable, 
they indicate only moderate profitability levels given the project risk profile. In comparison, one 
of the Thai independent power producers, Ratchaburi Electricity Generating Holding Public 
Company, has generated an average ROE of 20.9% over the past three years. In the later 
years of the concession, particularly beginning around 2029, NTPC’S ROE levels increase 
significantly.  However,  this  occurs  only  because  equity  is  being  entirely  paid  out  to 
shareholders through dividends. The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) on shareholder 
equity provides a more meaningful measure of returns to shareholders over the entire life of 
the  concession.  The  FIRR  on  equity  over  this  entire  period  is  estimated  to  be  14.2%, 
expressed in real terms. Again, while this is adequate, it indicates moderate, rather than high 
returns to shareholders. 
 
6.  The return on net fixed assets (ROFA) earned over the concession is also consistent 
with commercial viability.  Average ROFA over the first 10 years of operation is projected to be

Supplemental Appendix H  2 
 
14.4%.  Like ROE, the ROFA increases over the concession period, particularly over the last 
5–6 years. This occurs because annual depreciation expense reduces net fixed assets to zero 
by  the  end  of  the  concession.  Therefore,  the  asset  base  on  which  ROFA  is  calculated 
becomes progressively smaller. 
 
7.  Profitability and returns to shareholders are sensitive to financing costs. Since the 
assumptions  employed  in  the  base  case  regarding  financing  costs  may  be  somewhat 
conservative, there appears to be some upside potential for higher returns than projected 
under this base case. 
 
8.  At the completion of construction, the debt-equity ratio is almost 2.6, which reflects the 
72% debt 28% equity project capital structure. By the end of the first year of operations, this 
declines to 2.1 and by 2014, the ratio is projected to be only 1.3 as debt is repaid. By the end 
of 2021, the company would be debt-free and remain so over the remainder of the concession.  
The debt service coverage ratio (DSCR) illustrates that the company’s capacity to generate 
cash flows sufficient to service debt is well within the range considered satisfactory. In 2010, 
the first full year of operations, the DSCR is projected to be 1.51. The average DSCR over the 
repayment period of NTPC’s debt is 1.58.  The minimum DSCR is 1.48, which is considered to 
be satisfactory. This minimum DSCR may occur in a number of years over the concession 
period.
